Array() constructor
Array.from() has an optional parameter mapFn, which allows you to execute a map() function on each element of the array being created.

Array.from() has an optional parameter mapFn, which allows you to execute a map function on each element of the array (or subclass object) that is being created. More clearly, Array.from(obj, mapFn, thisArg) has the same result as Array.from(obj).map(mapFn, thisArg), except that it does not create an intermediate array. This is especially important for certain array subclasses, like typed arrays, since the intermediate array would necessarily have values truncated to fit into the appropriate type.
trans-unit.target: Array.from() tiene un parámetro opcional mapFn , que le permite ejecutar una función de map a en cada elemento de la matriz (u objeto de subclase) que se está creando. Más claramente, Array.from(obj, mapFn, thisArg) tiene el mismo resultado que Array.from(obj).map(mapFn, thisArg) , excepto que no crea una matriz intermedia. Esto es especialmente importante para ciertas subclases de matrices, como matrices con tipo , ya que la matriz intermedia necesariamente tendría valores truncados para encajar en el tipo apropiado.

trans-unit.source: Array.from() proposal
Array.from() was added to the ECMA-262 standard in the 6th Edition (ES2015). As such, it may not be present in other implementations of the standard.

Array.from was added to the ECMA-262 standard in the 6th edition (ES2015); as such it may not be present in other implementations of the standard. You can work around this by inserting the following code at the beginning of your scripts, allowing use of Array.from in implementations that don't natively support it. This algorithm is exactly the one specified in ECMA-262, 6th edition, assuming Object and TypeError have their original values and that callback.call evaluates to the original value of Function.prototype.call. In addition, since true iterables can not be polyfilled, this implementation does not support generic iterables as defined in the 6th edition of ECMA-262.
trans-unit.target: Array.from se agregó al estándar ECMA-262 en la sexta edición (ES2015); como tal, puede que no esté presente en otras implementaciones del estándar. Puede Array.from esto insertando el siguiente código al principio de sus scripts, permitiendo el uso de Array.from en implementaciones que no lo admiten de forma nativa. Este algoritmo es exactamente el especificado en ECMA-262, sexta edición, asumiendo que Object y TypeError tienen sus valores originales y que callback.call se evalúa como el valor original de Function.prototype.call . Además, dado que los iterables verdaderos no se pueden rellenar, esta implementación no admite iterables genéricos como se define en la sexta edición de ECMA-262.

BigInt is a built-in object that provides a way to represent whole numbers larger than 253 - 1, which is the largest number JavaScript can reliably represent with the Numberprimitive and represented by the Number.MAX_SAFE_INTEGER constant. BigInt can be used for arbitrarily large integers.

BigInt is similar to Number in some ways, but also differs in a few key matters — it cannot be used with methods in the built-in Math object and cannot be mixed with instances of Number in operations; they must be coerced to the same type. Be careful coercing values back and forth, however, as the precision of a BigInt may be lost when it is coerced to a Number.

trans-unit.source: Math.hypot also avoids overflow/underflow problems if the magnitude of your numbers is very large. The largest number you can represent in JS is Number.MAX_VALUE, which is around 10308. If your numbers are larger than about 10154, taking the square of them will result in Infinity. For example, Math.sqrt(1e200*1e200 + 1e200*1e200) = Infinity. If you use hypot() instead, you get better answer: Math.hypot(1e200, 1e200) = 1.4142...e+200 . This is also true with very small numbers. Math.sqrt(1e-200*1e-200 + 1e-200*1e-200) = 0, but Math.hypot(1e-200, 1e-200) = 1.4142...e-200.
Math.imul() allows for 32-bit integer multiplication with C-like semantics. This feature is useful for projects like Emscripten.

Math.imul() allows for 32-bit integer multiplication with C-like semantics. This feature is useful for projects like Emscripten. Because imul() is a static method of Math, you always use it as Math.imul(), rather than as a method of a Math object you created (Math is not a constructor). If you use normal JavaScript floating point numbers in imul, you will experience a degrade in performance. This is because of the costly conversion from a floating point to an integer for multiplication, and then converting the multiplied integer back into a floating point. The reason imul exists is because it is faster in only one (so far) circumstance: AsmJS. AsmJS allows for JIST-optimizers to more easily implement internal integers in JavaScript. Multiplying two numbers stored internally as integers (which is only possible with AsmJS) with imul is the only potential circumstance where Math.imul may prove performant in current browsers.
trans-unit.target: Math.imul() permite la multiplicación de enteros de 32 bits con semántica similar a C. Esta función es útil para proyectos como Emscripten . Debido a que imul() es un método estático de Math , siempre lo usa como Math.imul() , en lugar de como un método de un objeto Math que creó ( Math no es un constructor). Si usa números de punto flotante JavaScript normales en imul, experimentará una disminución en el rendimiento. Esto se debe a la costosa conversión de un punto flotante a un número entero para la multiplicación y luego convertir el número entero multiplicado de nuevo en un punto flotante. La razón por la que imul existe es porque es más rápido en una sola circunstancia (hasta ahora): AsmJS. AsmJS permite que los optimizadores JIST implementen más fácilmente enteros internos en JavaScript. Multiplicar dos números almacenados internamente como enteros (que solo es posible con AsmJS) con imul es la única circunstancia potencial en la que Math.imul puede resultar eficaz en los navegadores actuales.

trans-unit.source: Object.entries() returns an array whose elements are arrays corresponding to the enumerable string-keyed property [key, value] pairs found directly upon object. The ordering of the properties is the same as that given by looping over the property values of the object manually.

trans-unit.source: Object.getOwnPropertyNames() returns an array whose elements are strings corresponding to the enumerable and non-enumerable properties found directly upon obj. The ordering of the enumerable properties in the array is consistent with the ordering exposed by a for...in loop (or by Object.keys()) over the properties of the object. The ordering of the non-enumerable properties in the array, and among the enumerable properties, is not defined.
trans-unit.target: Object.getOwnPropertyNames() devuelve una matriz cuyos elementos son cadenas correspondientes a las propiedades enumerables y no enumerables que se encuentran directamente en obj . El orden de las propiedades no enumerables en la matriz y entre las propiedades enumerables no está definido.

trans-unit.source: Object.getOwnPropertyNames() returns an array whose elements are strings corresponding to the enumerable and non-enumerable properties found directly in a given object obj. The ordering of the enumerable properties in the array is consistent with the ordering exposed by a for...in loop (or by Object.keys()) over the properties of the object. According to ES6, the integer keys of the object (both enumerable and non-enumerable) are added in ascending order to the array first, followed by the string keys in the order of insertion.

trans-unit.source: Promise.all() will reject immediately upon any of the input promises rejecting. In comparison, the promise returned by Promise.allSettled() will wait for all input promises to complete, regardless of whether or not one rejects. Consequently, it will always return the final result of every promise and function from the input iterable.
Promise.all fail-fast behaviour
trans-unit.target: Promise.all comportamiento a prueba de fallas

trans-unit.source: Promise.all is rejected if any of the elements are rejected. For example, if you pass in four promises that resolve after a timeout and one promise that rejects immediately, then Promise.all will reject immediately.
trans-unit.target: Promise.all se rechaza si se rechaza alguno de los elementos. Por ejemplo, si aprueba cuatro promesas que se resuelven después de un tiempo de espera y una promesa que se rechaza inmediatamente, Promise.all se rechazará inmediatamente.

trans-unit.source: Promise.all waits for all fulfillments (or the first rejection).
trans-unit.target: Promise.all espera todos los cumplimientos (o el primer rechazo).

trans-unit.source: Promise.any() rejects with an AggregateError if no promise fulfils.
Promise.any() resolves with the first promise to fulfil, even if a promise rejects first. This is in contrast to Promise.race(), which resolves or rejects with the first promise to settle.

Promise.any() takes an iterable of Promise objects and, as soon as one of the promises in the iterable fulfills, returns a single promise that resolves with the value from that promise. If no promises in the iterable fulfill (if all of the given promises are rejected), then the returned promise is rejected with an AggregateError, a new subclass of Error that groups together individual errors. Essentially, this method is the opposite of Promise.all().

trans-unit.source: eval() is a dangerous function, which executes the code it's passed with the privileges of the caller. If you run eval() with a string that could be affected by a malicious party, you may end up running malicious code on the user's machine with the permissions of your webpage / extension. More importantly, a third-party code can see the scope in which eval() was invoked, which can lead to possible attacks in ways to which the similar Function is not susceptible.
trans-unit.target: eval() es una función peligrosa, que ejecuta el código que se pasa con los privilegios de la persona que llama. Si ejecuta eval() con una cadena que podría verse afectada por una parte maliciosa, puede terminar ejecutando código malicioso en la máquina del usuario con los permisos de su página web / extensión. Más importante aún, un código de terceros puede ver el alcance en el que se invocó eval() , lo que puede conducir a posibles ataques en formas a las que la Function similar no es susceptible.

trans-unit.source: eval() is a function property of the global object.
trans-unit.target: eval() es una propiedad de función del objeto global.

trans-unit.source: eval() is also slower than the alternatives, since it has to invoke the JS interpreter, while many other constructs are optimized by modern JS engines.
trans-unit.target: eval() también es más lento que las alternativas, ya que tiene que invocar al intérprete JS, mientras que muchas otras construcciones están optimizadas por motores JS modernos.

trans-unit.source: eval() is also slower than the alternatives, since it has to invoke the JavaScript interpreter, while many other constructs are optimized by modern JS engines.

filter() calls a provided callback function once for each element in an array, and constructs a new array of all the values for which callback returns a value that coerces to true. callback is invoked only for indexes of the array which have assigned values; it is not invoked for indexes which have been deleted or which have never been assigned values. Array elements which do not pass the callback test are simply skipped, and are not included in the new array.

trans-unit.source: flatMap can be used as a way to add and remove items (modify the number of items) during a map. In other words, it allows you to map many items to many items (by handling each input item separately), rather than always one-to-one. In this sense, it works like the opposite of filter. Simply return a 1-element array to keep the item, a multiple-element array to add items, or a 0-element array to remove the item.

trans-unit.source: let allows you to declare variables that are limited in scope to the block, statement, or expression on which it is used. This is unlike the var keyword, which defines a variable globally, or locally to an entire function regardless of block scope.
trans-unit.target: let le permite declarar variables que tienen un alcance limitado al bloque, declaración o expresión en la que se usa. Esto es diferente a la palabra clave var , que define una variable globalmente o localmente a una función completa independientemente del alcance del bloque.

trans-unit.source: let allows you to declare variables that are limited to the scope of a block statement, or expression on which it is used, unlike the var keyword, which declares a variable globally, or locally to an entire function regardless of block scope. The other difference between var and let is that the latter is initialized to a value only when a parser evaluates it (see below).

let bindings are created at the top of the (block) scope containing the declaration, commonly referred to as "hoisting". Unlike variables declared with var, which will start with the value undefined, let variables are not initialized until their definition is evaluated. Accessing the variable before the initialization results in a ReferenceError. The variable is in a "temporal dead zone" from the start of the block until the initialization is processed.
trans-unit.target: let enlaces de let se crean en la parte superior del alcance (bloque) que contiene la declaración, comúnmente conocida como "elevación". A diferencia de las variables declaradas con var , que comenzará con el valor undefined , let variables no inicializadas hasta que se evalúe su definición. Acceder a la variable antes de la inicialización da como resultado un ReferenceError . La variable está en una "zona muerta temporal" desde el inicio del bloque hasta que se procesa la inicialización.

trans-unit.source: parseFloat converts BigInt syntax to Numbers, losing precision. This happens because the trailing n character is discarded.
parseFloat is a function property of the global object.
parseFloat is a top-level function and is not associated with any object.
trans-unit.target: parseFloat es una función de nivel superior y no está asociada con ningún objeto.

trans-unit.source: parseFloat is also able to parse an object if it has a toString or valueOf method defined. The returned value is the same as if parseFloat had been called on the result of calling that method.
trans-unit.target: parseFloat también puede analizar un objeto si tiene un método toString o valueOf definido. El valor devuelto es el mismo que si se hubiera llamado a parseFloat en el resultado de llamar a ese método.

trans-unit.source: parseFloat parses its argument, and returns a floating point number. If it encounters a character other than a sign (+ or -), numeral (0-9), a decimal point, or an exponent, it returns the value up to that point and ignores that character and all succeeding characters. Leading and trailing spaces are allowed.
trans-unit.target: parseFloat analiza su argumento y devuelve un número de punto flotante. Si encuentra un carácter que no sea un signo (+ o -), un número (0-9), un punto decimal o un exponente, devuelve el valor hasta ese punto e ignora ese carácter y todos los caracteres siguientes. Se permiten espacios al principio y al final.

parseInt doesn't work with numeric separators:

parseInt understands exactly two signs: + for positive, and - for negative (since ECMAScript 1). It is done as an initial step in the parsing after whitespace is removed. If no signs are found, the algorithm moves to the following step; otherwise, it removes the sign and runs the number-parsing on the rest of the string.

trans-unit.source: some() executes the callback function once for each element present in the array until it finds one where callback returns a truthy value (a value that becomes true when converted to a Boolean). If such an element is found, some() immediately returns true. Otherwise, some() returns false. callback is invoked only for indexes of the array which have assigned values; it is not invoked for indexes which have been deleted or which have never been assigned values.
trans-unit.target: some() ejecuta la función de callback una vez para cada elemento presente en la matriz hasta que encuentra uno en el que la callback devuelve un valor verdadero (un valor que se convierte en verdadero cuando se convierte en un booleano). Si se encuentra tal elemento, some() inmediatamente devuelve true . De lo contrario, some() devuelve false . callback se invoca solo para los índices de la matriz que tienen valores asignados; no se invoca para índices que se han eliminado o a los que nunca se les han asignado valores.

trans-unit.source: Any JSON text is a valid JavaScript expression...

Any JSON text is a valid JavaScript expression – but only in JavaScript engines that have implemented the proposal to make all JSON text valid ECMA-262. In engines that haven't implemented the proposal, U+2028 LINE SEPARATOR and U+2029 PARAGRAPH SEPARATOR are allowed in string literals and property keys in JSON; but their use in these features in JavaScript literals is a SyntaxError.
trans-unit.target: Cualquier texto JSON es una expresión JavaScript válida , pero solo en motores JavaScript que han implementado la propuesta para hacer que todo el texto JSON sea válido ECMA-262 . En los motores que no han implementado la propuesta, se permiten U + 2028 LINE SEPARATOR y U + 2029 PARAGRAPH SEPARATOR en literales de cadena y claves de propiedad en JSON; pero su uso en estas características en literales de JavaScript es un SyntaxError .

Arithmetic operators take numerical values (either literals or variables) as their operands and return a single numerical value. The standard arithmetic operators are addition (+), subtraction (-), multiplication (*), and division (/).
trans-unit.target: Los operadores aritméticos toman valores numéricos (literales o variables) como sus operandos y devuelven un único valor numérico. Los operadores aritméticos estándar son suma (+), resta (-), multiplicación (*) y división (/).

trans-unit.source: Be careful. While it is possible to use it as an identifier (variable name) in any scope other than the global scope (because undefined is not a reserved word), doing so is a very bad idea that will make your code difficult to maintain and debug.

Bitwise operators treat their operands as a sequence of 32 bits (zeroes and ones), rather than as decimal, hexadecimal, or octal numbers. For example, the decimal number nine has a binary representation of 1001. Bitwise operators perform their operations on such binary representations, but they return standard JavaScript numerical values.
trans-unit.target: Los operadores bit a bit tratan sus operandos como una secuencia de 32 bits (ceros y unos), en lugar de numbers decimales, hexadecimales u octales . Por ejemplo, el número decimal nueve tiene una representación binaria de 1001. Los operadores bit a bit realizan sus operaciones en dichas representaciones binarias, pero devuelven valores numéricos estándar de JavaScript.

trans-unit.source: Contra: The with statement forces the specified object to be searched first for all name lookups. Therefore all identifiers that aren't members of the specified object will be found more slowly in a 'with' block. Where performance is important, 'with' should only be used to encompass code blocks that access members of the specified object.
trans-unit.target: Contra: La instrucción with obliga a buscar primero el objeto especificado para todas las búsquedas de nombres. Por lo tanto, todos los identificadores que no son miembros del objeto especificado se encontrarán más lentamente en un bloque 'con'. Cuando el rendimiento es importante, 'con' solo debe usarse para abarcar bloques de código que acceden a miembros del objeto especificado.

trans-unit.source: Deprecation warning: Do not use unwatch() and watch()! These two methods were implemented only in Firefox prior to version 58, they're deprecated and removed in Firefox 58+. In addition, using watchpoints has a serious negative impact on performance, which is especially true when used on global objects, such as window. You can usually use setters and getters or proxies instead.
trans-unit.target: Advertencia de unwatch() : ¡No use unwatch () y watch() ! Estos dos métodos se implementaron solo en Firefox antes de la versión 58, están obsoletos y se eliminaron en Firefox 58+ . Además, el uso de puntos de observación tiene un impacto negativo grave en el rendimiento, lo que es especialmente cierto cuando se usa en objetos globales, como la window . Por lo general, puede usar setters y getters o proxies en su lugar.

trans-unit.source: Deprecation warning: Do not use watch() and unwatch()! These two methods were implemented only in Firefox prior to version 58, they're deprecated and removed in Firefox 58+. Important: Since compilation for large modules can be expensive, developers should only use the Module() constructor when synchronous compilation is absolutely required; the asynchronous WebAssembly.compileStreaming() method should be used at all other times.

Important: Since compilation for large modules can be expensive, developers should only use the Module() constructor when synchronous compilation is absolutely required; the asynchronous WebAssembly.compileStreaming() method should be used at all other times.
trans-unit.target: Importante : dado que la compilación para módulos grandes puede ser costosa, los desarrolladores solo deben usar el constructor Module() cuando la compilación sincrónica sea absolutamente necesaria; el método asincrónico WebAssembly.compileStreaming() debe usarse en todos los demás momentos.

trans-unit.source: Important: Since instantiation for large modules can be expensive, developers should only use the Instance() constructor when synchronous instantiation is absolutely required; the asynchronous WebAssembly.instantiateStreaming() method should be used at all other times.

Important: Since instantiation for large modules can be expensive, developers should only use the Instance() constructor when synchronous instantiation is absolutely required; the asynchronous WebAssembly.instantiateStreaming() method should be used at all other times.
trans-unit.target: Importante : dado que la creación de instancias para módulos grandes puede ser costosa, los desarrolladores solo deben usar el constructor Instance() cuando la instanciación sincrónica sea absolutamente necesaria; el método asincrónico WebAssembly.instantiateStreaming() debe utilizarse en todos los demás momentos.

trans-unit.source: Important: This method is not the most efficient way of fetching and instantiating wasm modules. If at all possible, you should use the newer WebAssembly.instantiateStreaming() method instead, which fetches, compiles, and instantiates a module all in one step, directly from the raw bytecode, so doesn't require conversion to an ArrayBuffer.

Important: This method is not the most efficient way of fetching and instantiating wasm modules. If at all possible, you should use the newer WebAssembly.instantiateStreaming() method instead, which fetches, compiles, and instantiates a module all in one step, directly from the raw bytecode, so doesn't require conversion to an ArrayBuffer.
trans-unit.target: Importante : este método no es la forma más eficaz de recuperar y crear instancias de módulos wasm. Si es posible, debe usar el método WebAssembly.instantiateStreaming() lugar, que busca, compila y crea una instancia de un módulo en un solo paso, directamente desde el ArrayBuffer , por lo que no requiere conversión a un ArrayBuffer .

trans-unit.source: Not to be confused with: Several other languages have mechanisms for lazy evaluation and deferring a computation, which they also call "promises", e.g. Scheme. Promises in JavaScript represent processes that are already happening, which can be chained with callback functions. If you are looking to lazily evaluate an expression, consider the arrow function with no arguments: f = () => expression to create the lazily-evaluated expression, and f() to evaluate.

Not to be confused with: Several other languages have mechanisms for lazy evaluation and deferring a computation, which they also call "promises", e.g. Scheme. Promises in JavaScript represent processes which are already happening, which can be chained with callback functions. If you are looking to lazily evaluate an expression, consider the arrow function with no arguments: f = () => expression to create the lazily-evaluated expression, and f() to evaluate.
trans-unit.target: No confundir con: Varios otros lenguajes tienen mecanismos para la evaluación perezosa y aplazar un cálculo, que también llaman "promesas", por ejemplo, Scheme. Las promesas en JavaScript representan procesos que ya están sucediendo, que se pueden encadenar con funciones de devolución de llamada. Si está buscando evaluar una expresión de manera perezosa, considere la función de flecha sin argumentos: f = () => expression para crear la expresión evaluada de manera perezosa y f() para evaluar.

trans-unit.source: Note : In UTF-16, Unicode characters above \uFFFF are encoded as two surrogate code units, of the range \uD800-\uDFFF. The value of each code unit is taken separately into account for the comparison. Thus the character formed by the surrogate pair \uD655\uDE55 will be sorted before the character \uFF3A.
trans-unit.target: Nota: En UTF-16, los caracteres Unicode por encima de \uFFFF se codifican como dos unidades de código sustitutas, del rango \uD800 - \uDFFF . El valor de cada unidad de código se tiene en cuenta por separado para la comparación. Así, el carácter formado por el par sustituto \uD655\uDE55 se ordenará antes que el carácter \uFF3A .

trans-unit.source: Note: Where Date is called as a constructor with more than one argument, if values are greater than their logical range (e.g. 13 is provided as the month value or 70 for the minute value), the adjacent value will be adjusted. Similarly for other values: new Date(2013, 2, 1, 0, 70) is equivalent to new Date(2013, 2, 1, 1, 10) which both create a date for 2013-03-01T01:10:00.
trans-unit.target: Nota: Cuando se llama a Date como un constructor con más de un argumento, si los valores son mayores que su rango lógico (por ejemplo, se proporciona 13 como el valor del mes o 70 para el valor de los minutos), se ajustará el valor adyacente. Por ejemplo, new Date(2013, 13, 1) es equivalente a new Date(2014, 1, 1) , ambos crean una fecha para 2014-02-01 (tenga en cuenta que el mes se basa en 0). De manera similar para otros valores: new Date(2013, 2, 1, 0, 70) es equivalente a new Date(2013, 2, 1, 1, 10) que crean una fecha para 2013-03-01T01:10:00 .

trans-unit.source: Note: parsing of date strings with the Date constructor (and Date.parse, they are equivalent) is strongly discouraged due to browser differences and inconsistencies. Support for RFC 2822 format strings is by convention only. Support for ISO 8601 formats differs in that date-only strings (e.g. "1970-01-01") are treated as UTC, not local.
trans-unit.target: Nota: se desaconseja encarecidamente el análisis de cadenas de fecha con el constructor Date (y Date.parse , son equivalentes) debido a las diferencias e inconsistencias del navegador. El soporte para cadenas de formato RFC 2822 es solo por convención. La compatibilidad con los formatos ISO 8601 difiere en que las cadenas de solo fecha (por ejemplo, "1970-01-01") se tratan como UTC, no como locales.

trans-unit.source: Note:async functions created with the AsyncFunction constructor do not create closures to their creation contexts; they are always created in the global scope. When running them, they will only be able to access their own local variables and global ones, not the ones from the scope in which the AsyncFunction constructor was called. This is different from using eval with code for an async function expression.
trans-unit.target: Nota: las async functions creadas con el constructor AsyncFunction no crean cierres para sus contextos de creación; siempre se crean en el ámbito global. Al ejecutarlos, solo podrán acceder a sus propias variables locales y globales, no a las del ámbito en el que se AsyncFunction constructor AsyncFunction . Esto es diferente de usar eval con código para una expresión de función asíncrona.

Note:generator function created with the GeneratorFunction constructor do not create closures to their creation contexts; they always are created in the global scope. When running them, they will only be able to access their own local variables and global ones, not the ones from the scope in which the GeneratorFunction constructor was called. This is different from using eval with code for a generator function expression.
trans-unit.target: Nota: la generator function creada con el constructor GeneratorFunction no crea cierres para sus contextos de creación; siempre se crean en el ámbito global. Al ejecutarlos, solo podrán acceder a sus propias variables locales y globales, no a las del ámbito en el que se llamó al constructor GeneratorFunction . Esto es diferente de usar eval con código para una expresión de función generadora.

trans-unit.source: Note: A promise is said to be settled if it is either fulfilled or rejected, but not pending. You will also hear the term resolved used with promises — this means that the promise is settled or “locked in” to match the state of another promise. States and fates contains more details about promise terminology.
trans-unit.target: Nota : Se dice que una promesa está resuelta si se cumple o se rechaza, pero no está pendiente. También escuchará que el término resuelto se usa con las promesas; esto significa que la promesa está establecida o “bloqueada” para que coincida con el estado de otra promesa. Estados y destinos contiene más detalles sobre la terminología de las promesas.

Pro: The with statement can help reduce file size by reducing the need to repeat a lengthy object reference without performance penalty. The scope chain change required by 'with' is not computationally expensive. Use of 'with' will relieve the interpreter of parsing repeated object references. Note, however, that in many cases this benefit can be achieved by using a temporary variable to store a reference to the desired object.
trans-unit.target: Ventaja: la declaración with puede ayudar a reducir el tamaño del archivo al reducir la necesidad de repetir una referencia de objeto extensa sin afectar el rendimiento. El cambio de cadena de alcance requerido por 'con' no es computacionalmente costoso. El uso de 'con' aliviará al intérprete de analizar las referencias a objetos repetidas. Sin embargo, tenga en cuenta que en muchos casos este beneficio se puede lograr utilizando una variable temporal para almacenar una referencia al objeto deseado.

Reflect is a built-in object that provides methods for interceptable JavaScript operations. The methods are the same as those of proxy handlers. Reflect is not a function object, so it's not constructible.

trans-unit.source: Reflect is a built-in object that provides methods for interceptable JavaScript operations. The methods are the same as those of proxy handlers. Reflect is not a function object, so it's not constructible.

trans-unit.source: Spread syntax (...) allows an iterable such as an array expression or string to be expanded in places where zero or more arguments (for function calls) or elements (for array literals) are expected, or an object expression to be expanded in places where zero or more key-value pairs (for object literals) are expected.

Spread syntax allows an iterable such as an array expression or string to be expanded in places where zero or more arguments (for function calls) or elements (for array literals) are expected, or an object expression to be expanded in places where zero or more key-value pairs (for object literals) are expected.
trans-unit.target: La sintaxis de propagación permite que un iterable, como una expresión de matriz o cadena, se expanda en lugares donde se esperan cero o más argumentos (para llamadas a funciones) o elementos (para literales de matriz), o que una expresión de objeto se expanda en lugares donde cero o más Se esperan pares clave-valor (para objetos literales).

The iterable protocol allows JavaScript objects to define or customize their iteration behavior, such as what values are looped over in a for...of construct. Some built-in types are built-in iterables with a default iteration behavior, such as Array or Map, while other types (such as Object) are not.
The iterator protocol defines a standard way to produce a sequence of values (either finite or infinite), and potentially a return value when all values have been generated.
The literal notation's parameters are enclosed between slashes and do not use quotation marks.

Trailing commas (sometimes called "final commas") can be useful when adding new elements, parameters, or properties to JavaScript code. If you want to add a new property, you can simply add a new line without modifying the previously last line if that line already uses a trailing comma. This makes version-control diffs cleaner and editing code might be less troublesome.
